reviewText: Remember ordering a really cool looking game from a Scholastic Book Order back in school? Well, this game was one the gems I bought in third grade. The title is misleading because you can also drive golfcarts, dune buggies, and even fly planes or helicopters. It still has that same mid-2000s charm! The stadium crowds still punch the stuffing outta each other.\nI got this for 50% off and love it! Even though I played this as a kid, I wouldn't have bought it at full price considering today's pricing and competition. Runs fine on Windows 10 and doesn't need a CD/password for installation like the old-days.

reviewText:
Before you look at my hours, I would like you to know that I haven't played this game ever. Not on PS2, Xbox, whatever. However, I did play MX Unleashed when I was a kid, so therefore, I think I can review this game.

MX vs. ATV Unleashed is a great racing and freestyle game. Sure, you can play its races, but I barely knew anybody who did that. You know what I mean. All I do is goof off in Free Ride and freestyle. Now, let me talk about the main complaints, which I am going to defend.

1. This game doesn't work!
A: I know it doesn't always work. In fact, if you have Intel HD graphics, it won't work at all. However, here is how to fix it. Just launch the game and don't change any resolution, graphics, or texture settings. It's that simple. You can change the controls (Like I did because the default controls aren't good) and no crashes.

2. OMG! 30 FPS LOCK?!?!?
A: Yes, there is a 30 FPS lock. However, it doesn't affect how the game works. It's not like me where if it happened in an intense, precision game, where you need to instantly make decisions. Plus, this game is almost 10 years old. 60 FPS wasn't always the common things for games.

Those were complaints I saw most. I do complain that there is no open world like MX Unleashed. If there was, I would love this game to death. But even still, I still can't hate this game.

I would give this a 8/10. Just buy it now. And if you can't fix it, look on forums and then refund it.

reviewText:
Coming at this as being my first foray into the MX vs. ATV series, I have to say that I find this game a mixed bag.

The game isn't bad. For a game from 2006 it's actually pretty decent, if nothing impressive visually. Controls work well with a 360 controller and even support both joysticks for camera rotation, something that older pre-Xinput games didn't always do, and the racing mechanics are solid enough.

All that said, even in 2006 there were better games you could have been spending your money on. The game looks and feels like a budget title even for the time, with the licensed soundtrack being the title's real high point. The AI rubber bands like nobody's business, a feature racing games still have a problem with, and the lack of real impact your bike or ATV has on the course makes for a game that just doesn't feel great to play. Combined with limited graphical and gameplay tuning options and you have an experienced that is easily surpassed by any number of titles both on and off Steam.

The price point isn't terrible, but feels like it is somewhat more than the game deserves given its limitations and the game's overall forgettable nature. On the plus side, the game runs fine first-boot on Windows 8.1 with a full suite of modern hardware, so if you do decide to take the plunge there is little in the way of configuration needed to get it to run, though widescreen support would have been nice to see.

Recommended, but only for the fact that those with some sense of nostalgia for it shouldn't be disappointed by this version or its ability to run. For newcomers, though? Look elsewhere.

In order to use a controller you have to remap all of the controls; not that big of a deal, just annoying to do. Screen resolution is low as well. I think 1280 x 1024 is the max. It's not that big of a deal. Still the game I remember it to be. SO much fun.
